Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Adaptive differentiation, selection and water use of a seasonally dry tropical oak: implications for global change
Award.AbstractNarration: Climate change will alter key aspects of the environment for plants, such as temperature and water availability. Very little is known about how plants will contend with these changes, particularly species that are difficult to study, such as long-lived tropical trees. This project examines short-term physiological responses and the potential for long-term evolutionary changes in response to experimental manipulations of precipitation in populations of a tropical oak species that occur in different climates in Central America. The project investigates the extent to which these populations are adapted to the climate they currently experience and their potential response to climates that are similar to those predicted for the future. New insights will be gained as to whether impacts of climate change at the seedling stage enhance or constrain adaptation at later life stages of the tree. In addition, the research will identify the physiological and genetic mechanisms that enhance or limit adaptation to altered climates in this tropical tree. The project fosters the education, mentoring, and training of undergraduates, doctoral students, and a postdoctoral associate in plant ecological physiology and quantitative genetics at the University of Minnesota and at the University of Zamorano (Honduras). This work offers unique training and mentoring opportunities for Latin American undergraduates and para-taxonomists in Honduras and Costa Rica. It will also develop a collaborative, interdisciplinary network between researchers at the University of Minnesota, Cornell University, the University of Zamorano in Honduras, the Area de Conservacion Guanacaste in Costa Rica, and the Center for Ecosystem Studies (CIEco-UNAM) in Mexico.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our team examined the evolution of live oaks, Quercus subsection Virentes, with a focus on the tropical live oak, Quercus oleoides, using a combination of approaches, including phylogenetic and phylogeographic methods, physiological techniques, and quantitative genetic experiments including reciprocal transplants in the field and controlled environment manipulations in the greenhouse.

Using genome-wide data and fossil calibration, we determined that the American live oak clade, Quercus subsection Virentes, evolved within the last 25 MY and diversified into three major lineages about 11 million years ago (Fig. 1). We also showed that gene flow between species was strongest between geographically proximate populations and had the potential to mask phylogenetic and biogeographic inferences. Accounting for hybridization revealed a Central American origin of the Cuban oak (Quercus sagraena), a long-unsolved biogeographic question (Fig. 2).

Within populations, we found important genetic structure linked to biogeographic features in Central America and unglaciated North America. Within tropical live oak, Quercus oleoides, that has a broad distribution across coast Central America, we discovered a genetic break, dating to 2 million years, associated with the Nicaraguan depression and the Cordillera Guanacaste (Fig. 3). We predict the same pattern to be found in many other tree species that span Central America, an understudied region where such barriers are not yet well understood. The highly fragmented remnant tropical live oak forests in Costa Rica, which represent an isolated population at the southern range limit of the species, retains high standing genetic diversity relative to the rest of the species. A study focused on the disjunct Costa Rican population, showed that limited pollen dispersal causes significant spatial genetic structure but not local adaptation of subpopulations.

Across the geographic disjunction between Costa Rica and Honduras, Q. oleoides occurring in different climates also do not exhibit evidence of local adaptation.  When seedlings and seeds were grown in common gardens and under watering treatments, progeny from different populations showed evidence of water limitation but did not respond differently to the treatments. Despite the lack of evidence for local adaptation, we found significant selection on traits, including specific leaf area and stable carbon isotope discrimination in response to drought (Fig. 4). We hypothesize that high temporal and spatial variation in climate promotes the maintenance of high genetic variation within populations rather than local adaptation to specific climatic regimes.

In common garden experiments that include multiple Virentes species, we show that climate of origin predicts species freezing tolerance and demonstrate an evolved trade-off between freezing tolerance and growth (Fig. 5). However, variation in physiological tolerances within species is limited, indicating conservatism in climatic niches. Climatic origins also predict population difference in response to drought stress. Specifically, the accumulation of de-epoxidated xanthophylls, which are important for energy dissipation when photosynthesis is reduced by water stress, is positively associated with rainfall at the sites of origin (Fig. 6). Therefore, despite clear evidence for local adaption in field reciprocal transplant experiments, controlled environment experiments suggest a degree of broad climatic adaptation in physiological traits related to cold and drought stress.
